Name: Kenya Kangocho Full Flavor Roast
Review: ong>Intense but sweetly nuanced acidity should please those who enjoy a bright but engagingly complex cup.

Name: Kenya Karatu-Thika
Review: ong>The Kenya acidity is enveloped in rich, brandyish fruit and cocoa notes, making this a Kenya for lovers of fruit-rich red table wines.

Name: Kenya Tekangu Ngunguru
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a bracing, complex acidy sensation without a hint of sour bite; the acidity is wine-like and nuanced with pungent cedar and lush night flowers.

Name: Kenya Thiriku
Review: ong>A slightly bitterish but pleasing bite gives authority to this richly classic Kenya with its spicy floral and pungent berry notes.

Name: Kenya AA Kiaora Estate Full City Roast
Review: ong>Distinctive Kenya fruit in a superbly balanced, versatile cup.

Name: Kenya Giakanja
Review: ong>A balanced and complete medium-roasted cup, yet remarkable in its aromatic detail.

Name: Kenya Karatu AA
Review: ong>A brightly acidy coffee with complete and seductive balance and delicately distinctive, layered Kenya aromatics.

Name: Kenya Kiandu
Review: ong>A distinctive and intense yet balanced expression of the pungent/sweet fruit-toned Kenya character.

Name: Kenya Ruthagati
Review: ong>Lovers of bright, dry white wines and coffee lovers interested in an engaging variation on the classic Kenya profile.

Name: Panama Mama Cata Natural Process Geisha
Review: ong>An unusual pairing of the rare and distinctive-tasting Gesha variety of Arabica with an unorthodox dried-in-the-fruit processing nets a striking and exotic cup, rich, syrupy, savory-sweet.

Name: La Union Mexico Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Balanced Latin-American-style breakfast cup, sweetly crisp and fruit-toned with a hint of savory depth and solid social and environmental credentials.

Name: Original Roast
Review: ong>Heavy body and rich acidity in particular should help flavor pair with sweetener and/or whitener.

Name: Kenya Kirinyaga Kii Peaberry Espresso
Review: ong>Superb straight-shot espresso, smoothly balanced yet lively in detail. Loses its balance a bit in short milk but should power through considerable dairy in taller drinks.

Name: El Salvador Amarillo Yellow Bourbon
Review: ong>Presumably the influence of the Bourbon cultivar gives the fruit its pungent, roundly tart, raisiny richness here. Should please those who enjoy red table wines with dry, complex fruit character.

Name: El Salvador Los Alpes El Banco Pacamara Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the natural complexities of pure, high-end chocolates.

Name: Guatemala Finca La Candelaria
Review: ong>Wonderfully summery breakfast cup.

Name: Dharma Blend Espresso
Review: ong>Nice range of expression in the small cup, from peach-toned flowers to pungent cedar. Strong presence in two parts milk suggests it will hold its own in caffè-latte-scale beverages.

Name: El Salvador Finca Los Alpes Tierra Fertil Pacamara
Review: ong>Those who enjoy sensory distinction without acidy drama.

Name: El Salvador Finca Los Alpes El Banco Pacamara
Review: ong>Lovers of decisively dry but complexly aromatic white table wines should enjoy this very light-roasted coffee.

Name: Bard 2.2 (espresso)
Review: ong>Syrupy, deep straight shot; should make its presence felt in larger, caffè latte quantities of milk.

Name: Sumatra Lake Tawar
Review: ong>Superb, sweetly earthy, resoundingly complex Sumatra for those who already love Sumatras and want to move up, or those who have never sampled the type and want to at its best.

Name: Bard 2.2
Review: ong>Nicely balances the deep, rustic fruit of classic Indonesia coffees with a brighter Central America.

Name: Hojas de Otono
Review: ong>Those whose associations with autumn include the sweetly pungent, slightly smoky, deep, resonant.

Name: Colombia Cup of Excellence 2011 First Place Winner
Review: ong>Those who want to enjoy the assertively acidy but balanced and complexly nuanced cup that impresses international juries.
Coffee Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Costa Rica Las Lajas Honey Process
Review: ong>Low-toned complexity, smoothly lively mouthfeel and easy, approachable acidity should make this a comfortable but engaging breakfast cup.

Name: Espresso Nuevo
Review: ong>Superb straight-shot and short-milk espresso: big-bodied, complex but balanced. In tall milk retains flavor though a little light on presence.

Name: Espresso Classico
Review: ong>Its crisp, pungent brightness and sweet floral notes make it more trendy contemporary American than Italian, and the better for it.

Name: Guatemalan Puerta Verde
Review: ong>Pronounced but balanced acidity and complex, harmonious aromatics in a classic medium-roasted Antigua.

Name: Sumatra Lintong
Review: ong>A superb Sumatra; a wonderful introduction to this unorthodox type for those who don’t know it and a revelation for those who only know the sharply musty variety.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing district, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Costa Rica Santa Elena Espresso
Review: ong>Bright, sweetly acidy and resoundingly complex straight shot; sweet and gently chocolaty in short milk. Not a caffè latte or long milk espresso.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Dernaye
Review: ong>This unusual coffee should please those who find many admired coffees too acidy and intense, but who still enjoy distinction and originality.

Name: Nicaragua Cafe Alden
Review: ong>Those who enjoy simple, full-bodied, balanced darker roasts.

Name: Nicaragua Flor de Jinotega FTO
Review: ong>Those who prefer quiet depth to bright acidity with a bonus of impressive social and environmental credentials.

Name: Nicaragua Finca El Limoncillo Red Pacamara
Review: ong>A bit of a cigars-and-brandy style cup, deep, sweet but savory.

Name: Nicaragua Santa Teresa
Review: ong>Those who enjoy grandly acidy, big-bodied medium-roasted coffees.

Name: Nicaragua 5 de Junio Maragojipe
Review: ong>Light roasting develops the floral sweetness of this pure and delicate coffee.

Name: Mierisch Farms Pacamara Natural Process
Review: ong>Both those who have never sampled a brandyish, fruity style natural coffee or those who have and love them.

Name: Nicaragua Wiwili Organic Micro Lot
Review: ong>Those who prefer balance to intensity; smooth is perhaps the most overused word in beverage description, but this coffee defines it.

Name: Nicaragua SHG
Review: ong>Exemplary Nicaragua: rich, robust, deep-toned.
Coffee Origin: Matagalpa and Jinotega growing regions, Nicaragua

Name: Kenya Kagumo PB Special Reserve Micro Lot
Review: ong>Crisp, cleanly bright breakfast cup with a complicating hint of East Africa.

Name: Costa Rica Micro Lot “Pepe” Honey Processed
Review: ong>A grandly classic Latin-American cup: powerful but nuanced acidity, full mouthfeel, deeply expressed aromatics.

Name: Costa Rica Finca Las Gravileas Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy sensory depth and quiet authority. Rich and balanced when taken black, but should handle whitener well.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Costa Rica Finca Las Palomas
Review: ong>Clarity and balance in a crisp morning cup.

Name: Kenya Gichatha-Ini
Review: ong>The pungent Kenya fruit notes are high-toned and complex and the mouthfeel silky in this crisply balanced version of the Kenya profile.

Name: Kenya Gichatha-Ini
Review: ong>The pungent Kenya fruit is gently deepened by the roast, rounding complexity and softening acidity.

Name: Kenya Gichatha-Ini
Review: ong>The pungent Kenya fruit is softened and deepened without loss of its tart authority in this quietly complex version of the Kenya profile.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Koke Coop Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Delicately pure coffee, light-roasted to develop fresh, orchard-like aromatics and natural sweetness. Excellent environmental and social credentials.

Name: Nicaragua Cinco De Junio Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Crisp, sweet-toned lighter-roasted coffee with fine floral notes and excellent environmental and social credentials.

Name: Panama Gesha 2011
Review: ong>Coffee lovers with who don’t mind dropping significant money on a memorable version of the rare and celebrated Gesha profile
Coffee Origin: Volcán growing region, west and southwest of Volcán Barú, western Panama.

Name: Rwanda Coopac
Review: ong>Elegantly pungent and earthy, a good choice for those who enjoy fine Sumatras.

Name: Guatemala Xeucalvitz
Review: ong>An extraordinary coffee, subtle yet exotic, complete.
Coffee Origin: El Quiche Department, south central Guatemala

Name: Kenya “Karie” Micro-lot
Review: ong>Those in quest of the quiet, resonant side of the celebrated Kenya profile.

Name: Guatemala Guaya’b
Review: ong>Deep, tartly rich cup should please those who enjoy dry, complex red table wines.

Name: Guatemala Xeucalvitz Espresso
Review: ong>Distinctive straight-shot espresso, pungently fruit-toned and deep.
Coffee Origin: El Quiche Department, south central Guatemala

Name: Rwanda Musasa
Review: ong>Those who enjoy intense, challenging, strong-charactered beverages.

Name: Mexico Chiapas Fair Trade
Review: ong>Classically bright and balanced breakfast cup with impressive social and environmental credentials.

Name: Colombian Supremo
Review: ong>Lovers of dark roasts that combine crisp, roasty character with a full range of flavor and aromatics.

Name: Kenya AA Dark
Review: ong>Dark-roast fans who don’t need pronounced bitterness to convince them they’re drinking coffee. Displays solid dark-roast character while retaining sweetness and some Kenya complexity.

Name: Fair Trade Organic Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>A fine, balanced Yirgacheffe with muted aromatics. A good choice perhaps for those who find the lemon and flowers of most Yirgacheffes too brightly distracting and who may prefer a quieter, rounder version of the type with a fuller, more syrupy feel on the palate.

Name: Sumatra
Review: ong>Dark-roast Sumatra lovers, of which there are many. This version has less musty-earthiness and more chocolate than most traditional Sumatras.

Name: Organic Guatemalan Medium
Review: ong>Subtle, resonant-finishing Guatemala from a pioneer in sustainable coffee importing, roasting and sales.
Coffee Origin: El Quiche Department, south central Guatemala

Name: Thai Fully City Roast
Review: ong>A smooth, nut-and-chocolate-toned option for those who avoid brighter, more acidy coffees.

Name: Honduras Coprocael
Review: ong>Those who enjoy classically delicate light-roasted coffees, complex and lively.

Name: Ethiopian Konga Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a straightforward, briskly medium-roasted Yirgacheffe cup: silky, floral, lemony.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>Those who enjoy their lemony Yirgacheffe with an overlay of tactful roastiness and impressive social and environmental credentials.

Name: El Salvador Finca San Joaquin
Review: ong>Should appeal to lovers of dry, complex white wines.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Dominion
Review: ong>Those who enjoy complex but dry, challenging white wines.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who prefer an Ethiopia that minimizes delicate floral character in favor of crisp, lemony authority.

Name: Ethiopian Sidamo 2
Review: ong>Ethiopia flowers, lemon and cocoa nuance in a complex, bright but sweetly balanced cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Mexican Extra Fine Gourmet Coffee
Review: ong>A traditional style Mexico coffee, balanced and chocolate-nut toned. Should satisfy those breakfast-cuppers who prefer round and caramelly to bright and fruit-toned.

Name: Kenya Gethembwini
Review: ong>Simply a superb coffee, as grand as it is balanced and inviting, as fine with milk as it is black.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto
Review: ong>Quiet authority in a gently complex, cocoa-toned Guatemala.

Name: Guatemalan Antigua Sereno
Review: ong>Those who enjoy dry, delicate, minerally white table wines.

Name: El Salvador Finca El Carmen
Review: ong>Black coffee drinkers who prefer subtlety to drama.

Name: Ibonia Kenya Peaberry
Review: ong>Students of coffee distinction: The black currant note for which Kenyas are celebrated could not be more vividly and resonantly expressed.

Name: Ixil A’achimbal Guatemala
Review: ong>Balanced, quietly lively cup with a subtlety often associated with Guatemala.

Name: 1971 Nicaragua Viennese Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy assertively dry white table wines.

Name: Carmelo Yujra Bolivia
Review: ong>Lovers of dry, brisk, complex morning cups.

Name: Sumatra
Review: ong>A solid darker-roasted Sumatra of the pungent, earth- and fruit-toned style that over the decades has become a classic in North America.

Name: Brazil Ouro Fino
Review: ong>Richly low-acid cup with deep-toned fruit should please those who avoid brightly assertive breakfast coffees.

Name: Single-Origin Medium Roast
Review: ong>Smoothly balanced cup with an inspiring story.

Name: Ethiopian Medium
Review: ong>Lovers of White Rieslings and other crisp, floral-toned white table wines.

Name: Kiryama Kayanza Burundi
Review: ong>Certainly not Starbucks or dark-roast drinkers: delicate, summery, with the complex natural sweetness of berries and flowering grasses.

Name: Kenya AA
Review: ong>Big, intense Kenya with the celebrated black currant note in full display.

Name: Resiprocate Verita Espresso
Review: ong>A beautifully balanced darker roast for those who avoid assertive acidity and value natural chocolaty sweetness.

Name: Kenya Igandene
Review: ong>A big, bright, sweetly acidy style Kenya for lovers of classic medium-roasted breakfast cups.

Name: Exotic Medium Roast
Review: ong>An impressively pure coffee roasted to foreground its purity, as fresh as the lush hills of southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere
Review: ong>A classic version of the great Yirgacheffe profile, opulently floral yet pungently authoritative.

Name: Panama Los Lajones
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in masterful enrichment of profile through skillful application of an unorthodox processing method; anyone interested in a rich, complex, balanced cup.

Name: Candelilla Costa Rican Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who prefer depth to brightness in a crisp but comfortable breakfast cup.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Stars of Africa Blend
Review: ong>Lovers of the more complex, fruity but deep style of Cabernets.
Coffee Origin: Not disclosed, presumably East and-or Central Africa

Name: Decaf Guatemala Espresso
Review: ong>Given the rigors of decaffeination, an impressively balanced and complex espresso, particularly impressive in milk.

Name: Colombia Finca Cerro Azul
Review: ong>The great Gesha profile pure and uncompromised. Too intense and distinctive not to mention too expensive for many coffee drinkers, but try it at least once.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Organic Fair Trade
Review: ong>An exquisitely balanced Yirgacheffe, free of lemon zest intensity or over-the-top flowers yet still distinctive and unmistakable in its Yirgacheffe character.

Name: Guatemala SHB El Injertal Estate
Review: ong>Those who favor a medium-roasted cup with discreet fruit notes, balance and sweetness.

Name: Sumatra Aceh Gold
Review: ong>Elegant yet uncompromising in its Sumatra-ness, should appeal to lovers of the origin as well as making a good starter Sumatra for those purists resistant to the style.

Name: Colombia Camilio Torres
Review: ong>Fans of the deep and resonant style in Latin American coffees.

Name: Kilenso Sidama Natural
Review: ong>Ferment-toned fruit with grandeur and without shame.

Name: Burundi Kinyovu Micro-Mill
Review: ong>Those who enjoy complex variants on the celebrated, pungently sweet berry sensation coffee people call black currant.

Name: Colombia La Esperanza Micro-lot
Review: ong>Delicate, pure, gently bright; classic breakfast cup.

Name: Sumatra Aceh
Review: ong>Deep-toned, unorthodox profile for the single malt and cigar crowd.

Name: Sumatra La Minita Aceh Gold
Review: ong>Superbly elegant interpretation of the Sumatra earth and fruit profile.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Burundi Kinyovu
Review: ong>Poised between chocolaty and dry and citrusy, probably at its best in short milk, which rounds, softens and integrates its somewhat uneasy complexity.

Name: Peru Cruz Del Sur
Review: ong>Whether you follow Sean’s or Ken’s reading, a balanced, suave single-shot espresso and a standout in short milk.

Name: Mexico Nayarita
Review: ong>Those who enjoy fruity, slightly fermenty dried-in-the-fruit naturals should like this designed-for-espresso presentation of the type.

Name: Echo Blend Taiwan Espresso
Review: ong>Those aficionados interested in a fine espresso from a very rare coffee origin. As for the question of whether it expresses depth to support the citrus and honey, try it and be a tie-breaker.

Name: Single Origin Espresso Colombia El Paraiso Farm
Review: ong>An espresso for the new breed of straight espresso drinkers who value some of the same lighter-roasted brightness and honeyish complexity they find in drip-style coffees.

Name: Ethiopia Anyetsu Espresso
Review: ong>Expresses the berry-and-brandy character of fine dried-in-the-fruit natural coffees with clean, intriguing range and complexity.

Name: Brazil Moreninha Formosa Raisin
Review: ong>A cigars-and-leather-arm-chair-style straight espresso for those whose tastes lean to single malts and the more robust styles of tequila and grappa.

Name: Burundi Kiryama Micro Lot
Review: ong>African profile with enough savory depth to anchor the lemon and floral sweetness. Fine single-origin straight-shot espresso.

Name: Bolivia Caranavi Cenaproc Co-op
Review: ong>Superb and quietly distinctive straight-shot espresso; finely nuanced nut and chocolate.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Addis Ketema North Italian Espresso Roast
Review: ong>Ethiopia aromatic excitement rounded and deepened for your espresso pleasure.

Name: El Patron Nicaragua Espresso
Review: ong>For single-origin espresso aficionados this one may be a surprise (it was for us), with the dry depth and dark chocolate we associate with Brazils supporting a brighter fruit we associate with washed Centrals or East Africas. Go Nicaragua.

Name: Guatemala La Conception
Review: ong>Anyone who loves coffee, but particularly those interested in exploring the subtle but distinctive aromatics of the finest of Guatemala coffees.

Name: Kenya Ndiara
Review: ong>A Kenya for those who value great natural sweetness, thoroughly engaging complexity and silky refinement.

Name: Elevens Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy gently bright straight shots and delicately complex chocolate in short milk drinks.

Name: Burundi Kiryama
Review: ong>Finely balanced Africa Bourbon-style cup, without the aromatic intensity of a fine Kenya yet poised and resonant.

Name: Colombian Huila Suaza Coocentral Cooperative
Review: ong>Natural sweetness and balanced acidity make this coffee an ideal choice for those attempting to move their breakfast cup away from the sugar bowl and/or milk carton.

Name: Bolivia Familia Miranda
Review: ong>Impressive balance and completeness in a fine Latin-American style breakfast cup.

Name: Espresso Giusto
Review: ong>A nicely pungent and aromatic straight shot, but particularly impressive in short milk.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Yirgacheffe YCFCU
Review: ong>Those who enjoy fragrant but dry white table wines.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling Wahana Estate
Review: ong>Sensory adventurers. An exotic, ambiguous coffee with great fundamental sweetness and much, too much perhaps, going on aromatically. Definitely not for the purist.

Name: Tanzania Peaberry Tudeley Estate
Review: ong>A nicely balanced East Africa cup, gentle, quietly complex, with a hint of Kenya black-currant richness.

Name: Panama H2
Review: ong>Not intense, but many coffee drinkers may prefer it that way. Soft, balanced, sweet-citrus-toned.

Name: Rwanda Peaberry Coopac
Review: ong>A gentle, balanced version of the Africa Bourbon cup.

Name: Colombia La Escuelita
Review: ong>An almost miraculously pure, balanced coffee.

Name: Colombia Progreso
Review: ong>A classic Latin American coffee that should please those who avoid intense acidity but enjoy balanced, quiet complexity.

Name: Burundi Kayanza Gatore Lot 3
Review: ong>Not for the timid. Lovers of sweet citrus, flowers and powerful acidity.

Name: Java Blawan Estate
Review: ong>Delicacy and depth in a gentle dark-roasted cup.

Name: House Blend (paper pod)
Review: ong>Green coffee flavor taint muffles a potentially pleasing fruit-toned coffee.

Name: Senseo Colombian (paper pod)
Review: ong>Avoid this one and try one of the other Senseo pods.

Name: Kronung (Tassimo T Disc)
Review: ong>At least based on this sample, no one. I’ve tested versions of this blend in Europe and they struck me as dullish but decent. This version was little more than wood-flavored water.

Name: Sumatra Blend (Senseo Pod)
Review: ong>Those with brewing devices that use paper pods willing to put up with the wood to get at some Sumatra.

Name: Organic Sierra Verde Extra Bold (paper pod)
Review: ong>A decent-drinking organic and Rainforest-Alliance-certified coffee in paper pod format.

Name: Breakfast Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Richly roast-toned cup with a robust, roughish edge for Keurig owners.

Name: Voluptuoso Classic (Tassimo T Disc)
Review: ong>Almost voluptuoso. Tassimo owners who favor a smallish European-style cup dominated by a dry, slightly salty chocolate.

Name: Vermont Country Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A hint of the roast in a buttery, caramelly cup for Keurig owners.

Name: Fortissio Lungo (Nespresso capsule)
Review: ong>Pleasingly round, fruit-toned medium-dark roast blend in the European mode.

Name: Senseo Dark Roast (paper pod)
Review: ong>Good choice for Senseo (or Bunn My Café) owners looking for a dark-roast fix.

Name: House Blend (Tassimo T Disc)
Review: ong>Brewed short at 6 ounces an excellent single-serve rendition of a strong, Starbucks-style darker-roasted cup. Get it while it lasts, however; the Starbucks/Kraft breakup doubtless will wipe this T Disc option off the shelves.

Name: Indriya (Nespresso capsule)
Review: ong>Unusual opportunity for North Americans to try a very good European-style blend incorporating fine wet-processed Robusta coffees. Presence and gentle complexity without an acidy bite.

Name: Colombian LIght Roast (paper pod)
Review: ong>Genuinely captures some Colombia character: richness, ripe tomatoey and lemony acidity rounded by a hint of dark chocolate. Unfortunately, lacks carry-through in aroma and finish.

Name: Our Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Classic American-style breakfast cup for Keurig owners.

Name: Finezzo Lungo (Nespresso capsule)
Review: ong>A bright, classic breakfast-style cup for Nespresso owners.
Coffee Origin: East Africa; South America; Central America

Name: Colombia Fair Trade Select (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Keurig owners who prefer delicately bright white wines.

Name: Burundi Kayanza Kiryama Micro Lot
Review: ong>Offers a gentle cup with deep complexity.

Name: Beach Buzz Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy fine, versatile espressos.

Name: Papua New Guinea Boroida A
Review: ong>Offers depth, balance and considerable low-key nuance.

Name: Kenya Thiriku Top Auction Lot
Review: ong>Simply a splendid coffee, complete, majestic, powerful but gracious, meaning even those who avoid big, assertive lighter-roasted coffees should respond to this one for its sweetness, depth and balance.

Name: Kochere Yirga Cheffe
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in an intriguing, perhaps singular, variation on the great Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Kochere Yirga Cheffe Espresso
Review: ong>Versatile, distinctive espresso; powerful in the small cup, suavely pleasing in short milk.

Name: Ecuador Rosa Abad
Review: ong>Intensely aromatic, award-winning coffee.

Name: Kona Kama Lei Special Reserve
Review: ong>Graceful, fruit-toned, easy-drinking Kona.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Honduras Cup of Excellence Lot #17
Review: ong>Balance, delicacy and notes of lemon and cocoa in an award-winning coffee.

Name: Cup of Excellence Rwanda Lot #17
Review: ong>Engaging and original variant on the East Africa floral-and-citrus cup.

Name: Brazil Rodomunho Natural Espresso
Review: ong>Splendid straight-shot espresso: full, round, resonant, sweet and nuanced.

Name: Rwanda Musasa Red Bourbon
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a naturally sweet, round, cherryish-fruit- and nut-toned cup.

Name: Espresso Luna
Review: ong>Round, richly pungent, authoritative.

Name: Bolivia Carmelo Yujra
Review: ong>Balance and complexity in an outstanding Bolivia.

Name: Bolivia Familia Miranda
Review: ong>Classic Latin American cup: Nothing is excessive or out of balance; nothing essential is missing.

Name: Extra Fancy Kona Coffee Medium Roast
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in a coffee with a depth and range of aromatic expression that seems to define an almost singular sensory niche, brighter than Sumatra but deeper than East Africa.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, Hawaii.

Name: New Guinea Peaberry Goroka Waghi
Review: ong>Refreshing, edge-of-the-woods aromatics, clean but complex.
Coffee Origin: Waghi Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea.

Name: New Guinea Onaka Agoga
Review: ong>Quietly exotic, balanced, soft, exceptional.
Coffee Origin: Kainantu district, Eastern Highlands Province, Papua New Guinea.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo Natural
Review: ong>Rich, shifting complexity should please those who like oak-and-fruit dominated red table wines.

Name: Organic Costa Rica La Amistad Estate
Review: ong>Those who enjoy crisp, dry white table wines.

Name: Burundi Ngoma
Review: ong>Flowers and pungent, grapefruity citrus in a fine, balanced Africa coffee.

Name: Paretto Divino
Review: ong>Outstanding balance and complex citrusy chocolate in milk.

Name: Paretto Celesto
Review: ong>Fruit and spice overlaying bittersweet chocolate.

Name: Mon Ami Delight
Review: ong>A rich, raisiny chocolate is particularly impressive in milk.

Name: Mon Ami Bright
Review: ong>Delicate in body and flavor.

Name: Barista Blend #11
Review: ong>A cappuccino drinker’s espresso.

Name: Barista Blend #7
Review: ong>Sweet, silky, complex.

Name: Barista Blend #4
Review: ong>Those seeking syrupy complexity in the straight shot and balance in milk.

Name: Classic Roast Instant Coffee
Review: ong>Students of the sensory macabre.
Coffee Origin: Not disclosed. Contains coffee of the Robusta species.

Name: Instant Espresso Coffee
Review: ong>Perhaps dissolving a couple of teaspoons in hot milk with lots of sugar could produce a decent beverage for old-fashioned coffee-with-hot-milk drinkers.
Coffee Origin: Not disclosed. Almost certainly contains coffee of the Robusta species.

Name: Premium Instant Coffee
Review: ong>Skip it.
Coffee Origin: Not disclosed. Contains coffee of the Robusta species.

Name: Taster’s Choice French Roast Instant Coffee
Review: ong>Offers neither the rich, pungent bite that coffee drinkers look for in dark “French” roasts nor much of anything else.

Name: Italian Roast VIA Instant Coffee
Review: ong>Coffee drinkers who enjoy the pungent, robust richness of dark roasts will not find that sensation here. Inert, thin and unattractive.
Coffee Origin: Not disclosed. Composed entirely of coffees of the Arabica species.

Name: Original Instant Coffee
Review: ong>Not the worst of the instants.
Coffee Origin: Not disclosed. Contains coffee of the Robusta species.

Name: 100% Arabica Instant Coffee
Review: ong>Not good, but not the worst of the instants on the shelf.
Coffee Origin: Colombia. All coffee of the Arabica species.

Name: 100% Colombia Instant Coffee
Review: ong>Good price for a slightly less offensive instant than most.
Coffee Origin: Colombia. All coffee of the Arabica species.

Name: Classic Instant Coffee
Review: ong>Postum drinkers who want some caffeine.
Coffee Origin: Not disclosed. Contains coffee of the Robusta species.

Name: Colombia VIA Instant Coffee
Review: ong>A good coffee betrayed by the instant process.
Coffee Origin: Colombia. All coffee of the Arabica species.

Name: Taster’s Choice 100% Colombian Instant Coffee
Review: ong>One of the two best instants we tested for our March 2011 reviews. When hot relatively free of the various processing taints that haunt soluble coffees.
Coffee Origin: Colombia. All coffee of the Arabica species.

Name: Mocca Java Liquid Concentrate Coffee
Review: ong>Those who enjoy authentic but very delicate beverages.
Coffee Origin: Not specified, but most likely Ethiopia and either Java or Sumatra, Indonesia. All coffee of the Arabica species.

Name: El Salvador San Alonso
Review: ong>Intense fruit- and chocolate-toned cup.

Name: El Salvador El Optimisimo
Review: ong>Impressive natural sweetness and intense, complex aroma.

Name: Kenya Ruarai
Review: ong>Lovers of complexly bright, citrusy coffees.

Name: El Salvador La Montana Pacamara
Review: ong>A syrupy, savory-sweet fruit and rich complexity makes this a fine candidate for an afternoon or after dinner coffee, while the large, bold Pacamara beans are nice for coffee show and tell.

Name: Serendipity Blend
Review: ong>Those who appreciate effortless grace.

Name: French Roast
Review: ong>More chocolate and less char than usual in this French roast.

Name: Single Origin Medium Roast
Review: ong>A great story and a gentle, easy-drinking cup.

Name: Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>A fine rendition of the classic American breakfast blend: sweetly tart, refreshing.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe YCFCU Co-Op
Review: ong>Light-footed complexity in a classic Yirgacheffe.

Name: Rwanda COOPAC
Review: ong>Complex range of fruit from tart to sweetly lush.

Name: Panama Don Pepe Honey Processed
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in the unusual honey process, and anyone interested in a gently bright, lemony cup.

Name: Costa Rica Tres Rios
Review: ong>Citrusy excitement in this lighter roasted Costa Rica.
Coffee Origin: Tres Rios growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Guatemala Antigua La Flor del Cafe
Review: ong>A medium-dark roast softens the fruit and develops the chocolate in this quiet, balanced Antigua.

Name: Colombia Jardin Finca El Boton Maragogype Peaberry
Review: ong>An opportunity to sample a specially graded, unique variety of arabica with a rather unusual malty, woody character.

Name: Ernesto’s Espresso
Review: ong>Although evaluated as a standard brewed coffee, this blend displays the rounded acidity, full body and aromatic wood notes that play well in espresso brewing.
Coffee Origin: Fazenda Cachoeira da Grama, Mogiana Region, Minas Gerais State.
